results.title: Gippsland: open to the sea
results.creator_credit: Dione Gilmour, ABC-TV (Australia) and ABC-TV (Australia). Natural History Unit
results.brief_description: Part of “The World we share” series. Provides a study of life that abounds in the lake area in Gippsland. Shows the microscopic life in the waters of the lakes. Also notes the animals and birds that inhabit the shores such as the sea eagles that fish the lakes and the ant lion and the digger wasp that make their homes in the lake’s sandy shores. The mysterious moss ball swamps near the lakes are also looked at. Suitable for middle and upper secondary level.

results.title: Gippsland: Down river
results.brief_description: Shows how the floods that bring disaster to man in the Gippsland area play a key area play a key role in the natural cycle of the plant and animal life to be found there. However in the remote swamps and wetlands of the area, the cycle is threatened by man’s activities further upstream.

results.title: Gippsland: Through the forest
results.brief_description: Provides a look at the life forms of the Gippsland forest area. Here the world’s tallest hardwood tree, the mountain ash, towers to a height of one hundred metres or more and provides food and shelter at all levels, from the forest floor where the lyrebird scavengers to the tree tops which provide launching pads for the spectacular sugar gliders. Shows also the impact of the area’s two enemies: fire and man, and shows a rare glimpse of the family life of Australia’s laughing bird, the kookaburra.

results.title: Gippsland: the high country
results.creator_credit: Dione Gilmour, ABC-TV (Australia) and ABC-TV (Australia). Natural History Unit
results.brief_description: Part of “The World we share” series. Provides an exploration of the mountains in Gippsland through the changing seasons. Shows how the long winter surprisingly sustains a complex network of life underneath the snow. The brief spring and summer bring a rush of life witnessed in the vocal battle of frogs over territory, the birth of a butterfly, the migration of cockatoos and the life style of the burramy. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: One planet - two worlds: five minutes to midnight
results.creator_credit: Alan Hart, Ian McFarlane and World Focus
results.brief_description: Examines the crisis of world hunger and poverty. Considers the economic division of the world and points out the possibility of a world catastrophe if the division continues unchecked. Stresses the need to launch a global attack on the problem to ensure human survival. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Production of commercial gramophonic discs
results.creator_credit: P.J. Brook and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: A look at the various processes involved in the making of a record - from the artists recording onto multi-track tapes, through to the marketing and distribution to the public. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Life in a tin = Vita in scatola
results.brief_description: Bozzetto’s satirical cartoon about the repetitious humdrum life of the average human being. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: It's new, it's neat, it's obsolete
results.creator_credit: Alec Lorimore, Jim Foster and Bailey Film Productions
results.brief_description: ‘Honest’ Louie Ballou, used-car dealer, explains to us ‘confidentially’ how fashion and gimmickry create obsolescence and how we can use commonsense to get the most for our money. This film is a vivid springboard for discussion of the concepts of fashion, gimmickry obsolescence, and value for the consumer.

results.title: Nobody ever died of old age
results.creator_credit: Herbert Danska, Films Incorporated and Henry Street Settlement
results.brief_description: Presents a series of character studies of what it is like to be old in America, as seen through the eyes of a young nurse and writer in both rural and urban settings. Reel two begins with a quick overview of the physiological signs of ageing. The film then examines the plight of old people, hospital treatment, old-age homes and accommodation in general. Good sharp dialogue used by main characters to highlight the plight of the unwealthy elderly.

results.title: Chocolate
results.brief_description: Shows people, including Woody Allen, Jonathon Winters and Jo Ann Worley, tasting a cocoa bean and trying to guess what it was. The film depicts, without narration, the manufacture of chcolate from the extraction of the nuts from the cocoa buds to the addition of sugar to the chocolate powder.
